page.title: 03ECOLOGY OF CODICOYE/WELWYN
page.content: The area is of a dry upland character, the average height above sea level is 115 metres falling to 75/65 in the river valley. The land is mostly clay with flints on the hilltops, chalk on the hillsides and river gravel in the valley. Rainfall is relatively low averaging less than 30 inches per year. Pollution of the air and river is negligable. Alder and willow trees grow near the river, oak and hornbeam in the wooded areas. The woodlands abound with wild flowers, bracken and fungi, but road improvement, close trimming and the use of pesticides have led to the loss of some wayside flowers. The district affords sanctuaries for wildlife and gamebirds. Public footpaths and bridleways are numerous and well used.
